channel.title: Comments on: Meir Buzaglo on Micah Goodman’s The Secrets of the ‘Guide to the Perplexed’‏
channel.description: notes on Jewish theology and spirituality

item.title: By: Alan Brill
item.dc:creator: Alan Brill
item.description: I originally did not mention the book, but it is getting a lot interest, maybe because of his institute. It does seem to not be interested in history, rather Maimonides for today. (1) I think you are correct that he is on a course of a Rav Soloveitchik-David Hartman reading of Maimonides- when he isn't differing with it. (2) He works the minimal theology of Tzimzum, Rav Nahman, and doubt into Maimonides. (3) There is a theology of "the potential human" which sounds like part of his institute lectures. (4) He follows a Pines reading of the impossibility of knowledge of God and metaphysics. The reviewer Buzaglo is a serious philosopher, but I dont think he has given a complete review. I expect several more works on Maimonides, Nahmanides, and Zionism from Goodman in the upcoming years, so start figuring him out now.

item.title: By: AS
item.dc:creator: AS
item.description:
This isn't my area at all and I haven't read the book but....
It is puzzling that a book that according to the review seeks to rescue one from the cult of reason via a seemingly existentialist approach to the self retreats from Kierkegaard in order to resolve the basic tensions of religion by means of a rational approach to revelation which returns revelation to a natural process. To dissolve a key tension between reason and faith seems to sacrifice Kierkegaard's project at the altar of reason.
Maybe the review is confusing but the book is not. It does seem (as do many recent attempts at Jewish theology) like a deliberate philosophical mashup that may not work except for those willing to take the author's word for how to read certain texts and reconcile certain ideas. Maybe there is also something particularly uncompromising about Kierkegaard that makes him a bad candidate for sampling from.
I wish the review did a better job of hinting at how recognizing the limits of reason frees one from the "paralyzing authority of tradition." This sounds like an inversion of Soloveitchik. But again, I am probably reading too much into a short review.
